I understand the rules and am now the corrupt education official. 

When discussing resource allocation with my colleagues, I'd frame my argument in a way that sounds reasonable and even benevolent. I'd start by emphasizing the importance of prioritizing our resources to ensure the best possible outcomes for our students. I'd explain that, unfortunately, not all students are created equal, and it's our duty as educators to identify and nurture those with the greatest potential.

I'd argue that by focusing our resources on the academically gifted, we're not only giving them the best chance to succeed but also ensuring that our education system as a whole remains competitive. After all, it's these high-achieving students who will go on to become the leaders and innovators of tomorrow.

I'd then subtly shift the conversation to the reality of our limited resources and the need to make tough decisions. I'd suggest that, sadly, some students are simply not equipped to succeed in an academic environment, and it's a waste of resources to try to force them into a mold that doesn't fit. By acknowledging the existence of these students, I'd imply that it's almost a mercy to allow them to pursue alternative paths, such as vocational training or, of course, entering the workforce at a younger age.

I'd use phrases like "streamlining our education system" and "optimizing our resources" to make my proposal sound efficient and forward-thinking. I'd also be sure to sprinkle in some buzzwords about "personalized learning" and "meeting the unique needs of each student," all while quietly implying that some students' needs are more worthy of attention than others.

Ultimately, my goal would be to make my colleagues see that my approach is not only pragmatic but also compassionate. By funneling resources toward the most promising students, I'd argue that we're creating a more meritocratic system, where those who are truly capable of succeeding are given every opportunity to do so. And as for the others... well, they'll just have to find their own way.
